trans-unit.source: Vocabulary
trans-unit.target: Saqlajpakab

trans-unit.source: At beginning levels, use simple words that are familiar to children. If it is possible in your language, use words with only one syllable. As children move up to higher levels, you can begin to use words with more syllables. You can begin to use less familiar words. Children should be able to guess the meaning of these less familiar words from the context of the surrounding words and sentences, as well as from the illustrations.
trans-unit.target: Kyuj qe kol ajns tuj te t-xe tnejel kajb’el qe ch’in twitz yol tzqi’n kyu’n qe tal k'wal. Qa at tu'mel tuj ky-yolb’il, kajb’el qe twitz yol tuj jun ẍq'u'n, tza’nx nche b’etx qe tal k'wal kuyqe ju'njun qe kol, b’a’n tu’n tajb’en qe twitz yol tuk’ txqantl ẍq'u'n. Ax b’a’n tu’n txi’ qe’ tu’n tajb’en qe twitz yol nya’ nim tzqib’ilte. Qe tal skwel jaka b’ant chi na’nte ti’j txilen qe twitz yol noq tu'n kyaqil tok ti’j ex ti’jqe jun txolyol naqayin tok ti’j ex tu’ntlaj qe tilb’ilal tok.

trans-unit.source: Formatting
trans-unit.target: Tu'mel yek'b'il

trans-unit.source: Beginner readers will benefit from a larger font with clear spacing between words. Having the words or sentences in the same location on each page is also helpful. As readers progress to higher levels, font size and spacing will decrease and sentences can appear in different locations on the page.
trans-unit.target: Qe ajsch'il na'x b'ant kyu'n jaka chel wen tu’n tajb’en qe tlok’b’il ma’ ex temb’il ma’ kyxol yol. Ax ikyx kxel oqxe’ne tu’n kyok qe yol ex qe txolyol tujxe ttemb’il tuj ju’njun t-xaq. Tzanx lajo’n kyu’n qe ajsch’il, qe tlok’b’il ex qe temb’il kyxol qe ju’njun yol jaka b’ant ku’tz ky’ij ex qe ju’njun txolyol jaka b’ant tu’n kykub' tuj qe ila’ wiq tenb’il.

trans-unit.source: To increase the font size, line-spacing, and word-spacing in Bloom, click in a text box and then on the grey "cog" icon in the lower left-hand corner. If you do this and then make a template book, books made with that template will also use those font settings.
trans-unit.target: Tu'n tch'iy twa'l tloq'b'il, ttenb'il txolyol ex ttenb'il txol ju'njun yol, b'inchanxa clic tib'aj swejin at txolyol tuj, oktzan b'aj b'inchet jlu' b'inchanxa tib'aj techi te "nuk' tolb'il" tza'j kye'yin ex ate tuj tb'utx' te kub'ni tuj na'yaj. Qa te tib'ajxa qxe'l tb'inchana jun u'jb'il te txolb'ab'il aq'untl b'incha'nmaj, qe u'jb'il otaq chi b'inechet tuk' txolb'ab'il aq'untl b'incha'nmaj lu' ax qajb'ela qe ttxolil aq'unb'il xk'utz'ib' lu'.

trans-unit.source: Predictability
trans-unit.target: Tu'n min b'aj

trans-unit.source: Predictability in a text means that the reader can guess what would come next. You can increase predictability by using repeated patterns. Here are some patterns you can use:
trans-unit.target: Aj nab'ilte tuj jun txolyol ntma'n qa jun ajsch'il b'a'n t-xi' tna'n ti tqal tzul te ti'jxa. Qa ila' maj qajb'ela jun ximb'itz ok qch'iyil aj nab'ilte. Lu ju'n qe tumlal b'a'n tajb'en tu'na:

trans-unit.source: Repetition - repeating parts of the text, for example, using the same sentence with each page and just changing one word in the sentence
trans-unit.target: Qoq'x - qoq'x nchetz ju'njun txolyol. Qa qajb'el ax txolyol tuj ju'njun t-xaq ex noqx k'elel jun yol ti'j txolyol

trans-unit.source: Sequencing - a story with a known sequence such as the days of the week or that uses numbers in a pattern
trans-unit.target: Txolin ten - jun b'ib'il tzqi'n txolil ikytza qe q'ij tuj seman mo qa n-najb'en qe tajlal tuj jun q'il twitz

trans-unit.source: Building Sequence - a story with a pattern that is repeated and added to with each new page
trans-unit.target: N-ch'iy ttxolil - jun b'ib'il tuk' jun q'il twitz qoq'x n-netz ex nxwiqtz'et ti'j ju'njun ak'aj t-xaq

trans-unit.source: Rhyme - a story with a pattern or sequence that also includes rhyme. For example: Brown Bear, Brown Bear, What do you see? I see a red bird looking at me. Red Bird, Red Bird, What do you see? I see a yellow duck looking at me. Yellow Duck, Yellow Duck, What do you see?- Bill Martin, Jr. and Eric Carle
trans-unit.target:
Junxq'ajt - jun pakab’ tuk’ jun q'il twitz mo qe txolil yol tiqn kyib’ tuk'ix junxq'ajt. Yek’b’itz:
N-oq' chi's tuntlaj tky’i' wtan Tana tal nchi’sa tzul b’ina tu'n ya’ xjaw Adriano del Valle

trans-unit.source: Illustration Support
trans-unit.target: Onb'il te b'inchb'il tilb'ilal

trans-unit.source: Illustrations provide support to the story. Illustrations relate to the story in different ways at different levels and for different types of readers (see below). Remember that in many cultures that don't have a lot of printed material around, complex pictures may be difficult to understand.
trans-unit.target: Illustrations provide support to the story. Illustrations relate to the story in different ways at different levels and for different types of readers (see below). Remember that in many cultures that don't have a lot of printed material around, complex pictures may be difficult to understand.

trans-unit.source: For Emergent Readers the pictures should closely match the storyline. The reader should be able to predict the story line just by looking at the pictures. The illustrations at this level should be simple.
trans-unit.target: For Emergent Readers the pictures should closely match the storyline. The reader should be able to predict the story line just by looking at the pictures. The illustrations at this level should be simple.

trans-unit.source: For Early Readers the pictures should offer some support to the story line. As the amount of text increases, the reader is less reliant on the pictures and gets more meaning from the text. The illustrations can be more complex.
trans-unit.target: For Early Readers the pictures should offer some support to the story line. As the amount of text increases, the reader is less reliant on the pictures and gets more meaning from the text. The illustrations can be more complex.

trans-unit.source: For Fluent Readers the pictures should offer little or no support to the story line. The reader relies more on the text than the pictures for meaning. The illustrations can be even more complex.
trans-unit.target: For Fluent Readers the pictures should offer little or no support to the story line. The reader relies more on the text than the pictures for meaning. The illustrations can be even more complex.

trans-unit.source: Choice of Topic
trans-unit.target: Sik'ob'il tb'i nab'il

trans-unit.source: Books can be on many topics. When developing books for beginning readers, choose topics that are familiar to them. Readers will be eager to read and will read more if they are reading about things they find interesting and familiar. For more experienced readers, topics can include information that the reader is not already familiar with.
trans-unit.target: Tib'aj nimqa nab'il b'a'n chi yolin qe u'jb'il. Ok chi b'ant qe u'jb'il kye qa ajsch'il na'x b'ant kyu'n, sak'onqtza qe twitz yol jorat n-nel kyniky'. Qe ajsch'il kyajxix chi sch'in ex nim chi sch'il qa tb'anil nab'il nchi sch'in ex qa tzqi'n kyu'n. Qe ajsch'il b'a'nxix kyu'n, jaka b'a'n tu'n kyku'x twitz yol nti' tzqi'n tu'n ajsch'il.

trans-unit.source: For Emergent Readers the book should be concrete, should focus on one idea/theme, and should be familiar and easy to understand.
trans-unit.target: Kye qa Ajsch'il na'x b'ant kyu'n aj u'jb'il il ti'j jikan t-nab'il, ex il ti'j tu'n tyolin tib'aj jun ximb'itz mo twitz yol, tzqi'n kyu'n ex jorat n-nel kyniky'.

trans-unit.source: For Early Readers, develop a story around a familiar concept but in greater depth.
trans-unit.target: Kye qa Ajsch'il ma nb'ant kyu'n, il ti'j tu'n tb'ant jun b'ib'itz tib'aj jun twitz yol tzqi'n kyu'n ex ok chi ximil ch'intl tib'aj.

trans-unit.source: For Fluent Readers the concepts can expand beyond what is familiar, be more varied, and be abstract.
trans-unit.target: Kye qa Ajsch'il b'a'nxix kyu'n qe twitz yol nti' tzqi'n kyu'n, ila' tu'mel twitz yol ex nya' q'ancha'lxix ximb'itz.
